July 12, 2015: Fiction
THE GIRL ON THE TRAIN, by Paula Hawkins. (Riverhead.) A psychological
thriller set in the environs of London.
ALL THE LIGHT WE CANNOT SEE, by Anthony Doerr. (Scribner.) The lives of a
blind French girl and a gadget-obsessed German boy before and during World
War II; the winner of the 2015 Pulitzer Prize.
TRUTH OR DIE, by James Patterson and Howard Roughan. (Little, Brown.) An
attorney discovers a shocking secret that must be kept out of the wrong hands.
FINDERS KEEPERS, by Stephen King. (Scribner.) A deranged reader's
infatuation with a Salingeresque novelist has dangerous consequences in a
sequel to "Mr. Mercedes."
IN THE UNLIKELY EVENT, by Judy Blume. (Knopf.) Secrets are revealed and
love stories play out against the backdrop of a series of plane crashes in 1950s
New Jersey.
THE MELODY LINGERS ON, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster.) A
designer is drawn into the lives of family of a hedge fund billionaire who has
disappeared suspiciously.
WICKED CHARMS, by Janet Evanovich and Phoef Sutton. (Bantam.) Lizzy
Tucker and her partner, Diesel, join a hunt for buried treasure.
TOM CLANCY UNDER FIRE, by Grant Blackwood. (Putnam.) A former
collaborator continues Clancy’s series about the covert intelligent expert Jack
Ryan Jr. (Clancy died in 2013.)
THE RUMOR, by Elin Hilderbrand. (Little, Brown.) Two friends on Nantucket must
deal with damaging gossip about themselves and their husbands.
THE PRESIDENT'S SHADOW, by Brad Meltzer. (Grand Central.) In the third
Culper Ring novel, a severed arm is found in the White House Rose Garden.
RADIANT ANGEL, by Nelson DeMille. (Grand Central.) A surveillance expert
monitors the activities of a newly resurgent Russia.
COUNTRY, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte.) After her husband’s sudden death, a
woman falls in love with a country music superstar.
THE NIGHTINGALE, by Kristin Hannah. (St. Martin's.) Two sisters in World War II
France: one struggling to survive in the countryside, the other joining the
Resistance in Paris.

Non-Fiction
THE WRIGHT BROTHERS, by David McCullough. (Simon & Schuster.) The story
of the bicycle mechanics from Ohio who ushered in the age of flight.
DOWN THE RABBIT HOLE, by Holly Madison. (Dey Street/Morrow.) Life inside
the Playboy Mansion, by a former bunny and girlfriend of Hugh Hefner.
MODERN ROMANCE, by Aziz Ansari with Eric Klinenberg. (Penguin Press.) The
comedian enlists a sociologist to help him understand today’s dating scene.
DEAD WAKE, by Erik Larson. (Crown.) The last voyage of the Lusitania, the
passenger liner sunk by a German torpedo in 1915.
SICK IN THE HEAD, by Judd Apatow. (Random House.) Thirty years’ worth of the
filmmaker’s interviews with comedians.
THE ROAD TO CHARACTER, by David Brooks. (Random House.) The Times
columnist extols personal virtues like kindness and honesty in a materialistic age.
BILL O'REILLY'S LEGENDS AND LIES, by David Fisher. (Holt.) Stories of the
American West; a companion volume to the Fox News series.
BEING MORTAL, by Atul Gawande. (Metropolitan/Holt.) The surgeon and New
Yorker writer considers how doctors fail patients at the end of life and how they
can do better.
IT'S A LONG STORY, by Willie Nelson with David Ritz. (Little, Brown.) The
country music star discusses his life’s journey, from selling encyclopedias to
professional fame.
¡ADIOS, AMERICA!, by Ann Coulter. (Regnery.) The political commentator
denounces immigrants and their liberal supporters.
PRIMATES OF PARK AVENUE, by Wednesday Martin. (Simon & Schuster.) A
memoir of life among the wealthy women of the Upper East Side.
ELON MUSK, by Ashlee Vance. (Ecco/HarperCollins.) Musk’s life from his difficult
South African childhood to his involvement in Internet start-ups like the rocket
company SpaceX and the electric-car company Tesla.
AND THE GOOD NEWS IS ..., by Dana Perino. (Twelve.) The Fox News
contributor and former press secretary under President George W. Bush reviews
her life and career.
PIRATE HUNTERS, by Robert Kurson. (Random House.) The hunt for a 17th-
century pirate ship.
